results.name: Fiji: Tropical Cyclone sEAP, 2025
results.summary:
Fiji is one of the world’s most vulnerable nations to climate change and climate-related disasters. The country is exposed to multiple hazards including earthquakes, tsunami, landslide, coastal flooding, tropical cyclones, and wildfire. One of the principal hazards affecting Fiji is tropical cyclones (TCs).
 
Since 1969, there have been 33 TCs (Category 1 or higher) that have passed within 10 km of Fiji, and 16 that made landfall . Some of the most devastating cyclones to hit the country in recent history include Cyclone Winston (2016), the strongest cyclone ever recorded in the Southern Hemisphere, Cyclone Yasa (2020), the second-strongest cyclone on record to make landfall in Fiji, and Cyclone Harold (2020). Tropical cyclones negatively impact lives, livelihoods, the environment, agriculture, well-being, infrastructure, and the economy.  
 
According to Fiji Government estimates, by 2050, over 6.5 per cent of GDP could be lost due to TCs and floods, with the number of people pushed into poverty increasing by 25 per cent year on year . TC Winston alone impacted approximately 540,000 people, equivalent to 62 per cent of the country’s total population. It caused the loss of 44 lives and destroyed entire communities. Approximately 40,000 people required immediate assistance following the cyclone, and about 30,300 houses, 495 schools, and 88 health clinics and medical facilities were damaged or destroyed. In addition, the cyclone destroyed crops on a large scale and compromised the livelihoods of almost 60 per cent of Fiji’s population. The estimated effect of TC Winston was equivalent to F$2.0 billion (US$900M)

contacts.name: Katie GREENWOOD
contacts.title: IFRC Head of Delegation CCD Suva Office

contacts.name: Soneel Ram
contacts.title: IFRC Communication Manager CCD Suva office

field_reports.description:
In the aftermath of Tropical Cyclone Mal sweeping through Fiji waters, the Government is mobilizing rapid responses to ensure the safety and well-being of its citizens.

Strong winds associated with Severe Tropical Cyclone Mal last night damaged two electricity power poles along the Lomolomo-Sabeto Queens Highway stretch near Nadi. Motorists traveling through the area displayed caution when approaching a bend where the poles are located. Energy Fiji Limited said it noted that sparking powerlines as a result of strong winds had disrupted power supply which was affecting customers in the whole of Lomolomo and nearby areas in Lautoka. An EFL team is working on restoring power to the affected areas, however, this is weather permitting, and as soon as conditions are safe to do so.
Tropical Cyclone Mal has passed through the Fiji watersin the afternoon. Most warnings are set to be cleared, but specific cautions remain in effect for various regions, including Storm and Gale Warnings with wind speeds reaching Hurricane Force.
Currently, 180 active evacuation centers are operational across all divisions, housing over 6,381 evacuees from 986 households. The breakdown includes 84 centers in the Western Division, 49 in the Central Division, 37 in the Eastern Division, and 10 in the Northern Division.
In Wailoku, Vataleka, the outskirts of Suva, three families are seeking refuge in a community hall following a morning landslide. Authorities are closely monitoring the situation and providing necessary assistance.

Current Priorities:
1. Restoration of critical infrastructure.
2. Assistance to essential services.
3. Distribution of food rations to prioritized groups.
4. Mobilization of Initial Damage Assessment (IDA) teams.

Key Decisions:
1. All schools will reopen from tomorrow, with teachers contributing to the disinfection of school premises.
2. Non-essential civil servants are to resume work starting tomorrow.
3. Food ration distribution for active evacuation centers begins today.
4. Businesses and public service providers are given the green light to resume operations.

It is advised by the authority that as the nation collectively works towards recovery, citizens are urged to stay vigilant, adhere to safety measures, and support one another.

Tropical Depression 02F has intensified into a Tropical Cyclone at 6 pm today (13/11/2023) and has been named Mal.
According to the Fiji Meteorological Office in Nadi, TC Mal was located at about 655km West-Northwest of Rotuma and about 945km Northwest of Yasawa-I-Rara.
The weather office said TC Mal is expected to track to the west of Fiji within the next 24 to 48 hours and approach the group as a category 2 system.
“Expect gale-force winds to affect especially the western division from tomorrow.”

results.name: Fiji - Cyclone Mal 2023
results.summary: Tropical Depression 02F has intensified into a Tropical Cyclone at 6 pm today (13/11/2023) and has been named Mal. According to the Fiji Meteorological Office in Nadi, TC Mal was located at about 655km West-Northwest of Rotuma and about 945km Northwest of Yasawa-I-Rara. The weather office said TC Mal is expected to track to the west of Fiji within the next 24 to 48 hours and approach the group as a category 2 system. “Expect gale-force winds to affect especially the western division from tomorrow.”

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: From Ministry of Health source- number of suspected cases in the Central is higher than the numbers from the North but the North has already confirmed cases therefore focusing the 1st phase of this response in the North. This is to enable the affected communities to contain the spread of this outbreak to other nearby communities.
field_reports.description:
The Ministry of Health has declared a Dengue Outbreak in the Central Division particularly in Suva, with an unusual increase in dengue like cases presenting at its health facilities and admitted to the Colonial War Memorial Hospital.  Dengue Fever is endemic in Fiji, meaning it occurs regularly within our population. However, when there are more cases than normally seen, it is considered an outbreak.
Government health facilities in the central health division have been activated to ensure the availability of adequate manpower and the technical resources to accommodate the anticipated initial rise in case numbers of dengue fever infections.
In a coordination meeting called by the MoH, the Fiji Red Cross is preparing its team in their branches and headquarters to respond to the areas with confirmed cases, which are mostly in the Northern division. Current statistics, saw an increase in numbers of suspected cases in the Central division, but are awaiting lab test results to confirm confirmed cases. Therefore, more focus will be given to the Northern division to ensure that the spread of confirmed cases is contained.

Currently, Environmental Health Officers (EHO) are committed to Disease Investigation on case-by-case basis. Limited support on Awareness of outbreak to community due to staff ratio is one of the major issues the MoH is facing and are looking to its partners like Fiji Red Cross to support.  Competing priorities with other key FRCS community organised training and visits in these affected areas will affect its roll out due to this outbreak.

Below is the list of the most affected districts in the North and its communities.
1.	Labasa (7)- Siberia/Vunivau/Wailevu/Bulileka/Basoga/Tuatua/Vunika
2.	Seaqaqa (4) – Tabia/Seaqaqa Town area/Dreketi/Naduri
3.	Wainikoro (5) – Navoalevu/Coqeloa/Naleba/Daku/Lagalaga
This is looking at 16 communities in the 3 districts with a total of 317 confirmed cases. Majority of these confirmed cases are from the main Labasa town.

results.name: FJI: Epidemic - 2023-03 - Dengue Outbreak
results.summary:
The Ministry of Health has declared a Dengue Outbreak in the Central Division particularly in Suva, with an unusual increase in dengue like cases presenting at its health facilities and admitted to the Colonial War Memorial Hospital. field_reports.description:
Special Weather Bulletin #8 for HEAVY RAIN for flash flood issued from RSMC Nadi 11.19am on Tuesday 18th January 2022.
HEAVY RAIN ALERT A HEAVY RAIN ALERT previously in force for the Eastern interior, Eastern and Northern parts of Viti Levu, Northern Division and the Lau and Lomaiviti group is now CANCELLED. FLASH FLOOD ALERT CANCELLATION A FLASH FLOOD ALERT that was previously in force for all low lying and flash flood prone areas from Navua to Suva and Nausori to Rakiraki is now CANCELLED. SITUATION: A trough of low pressure lies slow moving over the Northeast parts of the group. Associate cloud and rain affect parts of the country.

SOURCE: NDMO SITREP #13

A SEVERE FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN FORCE FOR ALL LOW LYING AREAS AND SMALL STREAMS ADJACENT TO AND DOWNSTREAM OF; NAKAUVADRA RIVER (RAKIRAKI), NASIVI RIVER (TAVUA), BA RIVER, SABETO RIVER, YAQARA AND NANANU RIVER, NAWAKA RIVER, NADI RIVER, TUVA RIVER, WAIBULA RIVER(KOROVOU) AND REWA RIVER (WAIMANU,WAIDINA RIVER, WAINIMALA AND WAINIBUKA); For More Information Refer To: Https://Www.Met.Gov.Fj/Index.Php?Page=Warn1#20016.Txt
A FLOOD ALERT REMAIN IN FORCE FOR LOW LYING AREAS ADJACENT TO AND DOWNSTREAM OF; SIGATOKA RIVER, NAVUA RIVER IN VITI LEVU; QAWA RIVER, LABASA RIVER, WAILEVU RIVER, BUCAISAU RIVER, WAINIKORO RIVER, DREKETI RIVER, NASOROWAQA RIVER, LEKUTU RIVER, DAMA RIVER, WAINUNU RIVER,NASEKAWA RIVER AND YANAWAI RIVER IN VANUA LEVU For More Information Refer To: Https://Www.Met.Gov.Fj/Index.Php?Page=Warn1#20016.Txt
A FLASH FLOOD WARNING IS NOW IN FORCE FOR ALL LOW LYING AND FLASH FLOOD PRONE AREAS OF VITI LEVU AND VANUA LEVU INCLUDING SMALL STREAM IN THE OUTER ISLANDS OF OVALAU, KORO AND TAVEUNI.
For More Information Refer To: Https://Www.Met.Gov.Fj/Index.Php?Page=Warn1#20018.Txt
NATIONAL EMERGENCY OPERATION CENTER

149 Evacuation centres are open across the central, northern and western divisions (easter evac centres closed). Water supply remains an issue for most of the North. LTDD campaigns have started. Significant access issues remain in the north due to slips and flooded roads. Power remains out for some of the north and Western divisions. Food, water, hygiene and livelihoods.

Tropical Cyclone Ana passed the Yasa group islands around 10:00 pm last night and made landfall today at 6am as a Category 2 near RakiRaki and continued south-southwest across the central division towards Suva by mid day and onto Kadavu in the evening. At the centre were average 100km/hr winds with gusts of 140km/hr. Significant damage to trees, weal structures and houses has been experienced with heavy damage to crops and power failures. Rain is continuing, rivers have overflowed their banks and extensive flooding of roads, villages,  towns and communities has been reported. Very high seas and storm surge have been seen in the coastal areas. By mid-day TD07F developed into Tropical Cyclone Bina. Its path is expected to follow similar to TC Yasa and bring more rain.

contacts.name: Kathryn Clarkson
contacts.title: Head of Country Cluster Delegation, IFRC

field_reports.description: Tropical Depression TD05F intensified into a category 1 system and named Tropical Cyclone(TC) Ana today. TC Ana continues to move closer towards Fiji at a slow pace. It is anticipated to be located near the Yasawa Group tonight and approach Viti Levu early tomorrow as a category 1 cyclone. TC Ana is likely to make landfall over Ra Province tomorrow morning then continue to move southeastwards over Viti Levu close to Kadavu  Monday morning. Gale force winds have been reported over Yasawa-i-Rara this morning and are expected to affect the rest of the Fiji Group from later today. Damages to weak structures and houses of very light materials is expected. It may also cause disruption of electrical power distribution and communication services. Damages to crops and vegetation with trees tilting due to very strong winds is also likely. Heavy rain is expected to continue and become more frequent as TC Ana draws closer to Fiji. This will cause flooding of roads, villages, towns and communities near streams, rivers and low lying areas. Due to continuous rain in the last few days causing soil in the ground to become moist and loose, this poses risk of landslides. Moderate swells and breaking waves reaching the coastal areas may cause possible coastal inundation and sea flooding especially during high tide. Sea conditions are too dangerous for sea travel, sailing and other sea activities.

results.name: GDACS Orange: Fiji TC Hurricane/Typhoon > 74 mph (maximum wind speed of 120 km/h)
results.summary: From 30/01/2021 to 31/01/2021, a Hurricane/Typhoon > 74 mph (maximum wind speed of 120 km/h) ANA-21 was active in SEPacific. The cyclone affects these countries: Fiji (vulnerability Medium). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 0.29 million.

field_reports.gov_affected_pop_centres: Yasawa and Mamanuca Group, northern and eastern Viti Levu (from Nadi through to Korovou), northern half of Vanua Levu (from Nabouwalu through to Votua to Labasa through to Udu Point), Taveuni, and Rotuma
field_reports.description:
TC Yasa is expected to intensify and upgrade into a category 5 system as it moves closer to the Fiji group on Thursday. Continuous heavy rain will start to affect the group by Wednesday. Due to anticipated widespread heavy rain, there is risk of river flooding and flash flooding of low lying and flood prone areas. With the ground already saturated, there is also risk of landslides in landslide prone areas.
As TC Yasa moves closer towards the group, high waves of possibly more than 6 meters is expected which poses the risk of storm surge and coastal inundation along coastlines of Fiji especially over Yasawa and Mamanuca Group, northern half of Viti Levu and northern half of Vanua Levu from Thursday. Estimated wind speeds are forecasted for up to 185 km/hr  by 17 December. Authorities have cancelled schools, evacuation centres will be opening and agencies are preparing communities for early actions.

results.name: GDACS Orange: Fiji TC Tropical Storm (maximum wind speed of 185 km/h)
results.summary: From 12/12/2020 to 13/12/2020, a Tropical Storm (maximum wind speed of 185 km/h) YASA-20 was active in SEPacific. The cyclone affects these countries: Fiji,  (vulnerability Medium). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 29394.
